column1: Will the New START treaty be extended by Russia and the U.S. before 6 February 2021?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
Bumping my forecast up to 100% based on the Department of State press release from today (2/3/2021):
No change, just running out the clock now.
START treaty 5 year extension signed by Putin with little fanfare (eclipsed by the Nevalny fiasco) and will be validated through "diplomatic notes".
Too little time left and the 2 sides are not engaged in the negotiations.
Increased likelihood due to resources shared by @IVCoffeePlz and @ JHRoss
Russia signed the treaty 29 January.
https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/29/europe/russia-new-start-treaty-extension-intl/index.html

Increasing my forecast based on the article below. Although both sides have committed to extending it before February 5th, it seems like there is still a small potential for either team to run into a snag.
Voted on unanimously by the Dum and signed by Putin today. https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/29/putin-russia-us-nuclear-arms-treaty-463779

Finally bumping to 100%; diplomatic notes were exchanged: "The Russian lower house of Parliament, the Duma, on Wednesday ratified a new START nuclear treaty with the US. The United States and Russia had "agreed in principle" to extend the arms treaty by five years following a phone call between US President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin Tuesday. A Kremlin description of the call between the two leaders said they had both "expressed satisfaction" that diplomatic notes had been exchanged earlier Tuesday confirming that the treaty would be extended. The extension doesn't require approval from lawmakers in the US." https://www.dw.com/en/us-russia-agree-to-extend-new-start-nuclear-arms-treaty/a-56354318
I concur with the analysis of the other forecasters.
https://twitter.com/AP/status/1355195551554412548

Putin and Biden talked to each other, then the Russian Parliament voted to extend it, looks like they'll complete all the necessary steps on the Russian side by Wednesday. It doesn't require congressional action on the U.S. side so it will be finalized by exchanging diplomatic notes. This is going to happen, unless something really weird goes down this week.
@ajg it looks like you are spot on. https://www.dw.com/en/us-russia-agree-to-extend-new-start-nuclear-arms-treaty/a-56354318
Phone call yesterday between Biden and Putin to discuss plans for extension. Both leaders seem to be in favor.
Updated to 100% after POTUS' phone call with President Putin yesterday signifying that the extension is in the works.
Done and dusted.

bne IntelliNews Editor's Picks -- Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Joe Biden have first phone call, extend START II treaty for five years The top story today is US President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin talked for the first time yesterday and agreed to extend the START II treaty for another five years with no conditions attached.
Both of the contestants on the Vlad and Joe Show said yesterday they wanted to do this. Presumably they will.
Russia and US have agreed, says TASS. https://tass.com/politics/1249313
Based on https://www.dw.com/en/us-russia-agree-to-extend-new-start-nuclear-arms-treaty/a-56354318
Putin has announced that the US and Russia have extended New START. The White House has yet to confirm the news, but that story appears to be imminent.

"President Joe Biden held his first call Tuesday with his Russian counterpart, according to the White House, confronting President Vladimir Putin over a range of issues from a recent massive cyberattack to the suspected poisoning of the country's leading opposition figure. The call, which occurred midday, amounted to Biden's opening bid at diplomacy with one of his chief adversaries, whom he has met previously but not dealt with as an equal.[...] But he's also made an opening bid for diplomacy on the nuclear treaty, suggesting he is open to fostering a working relationship with Putin. 'I find that we can both operate in the mutual self-interest of our countries, as a new START agreement, and make it clear to Russia that we are very concerned about their behavior, whether it's Navalny, whether it's the Solar Winds or whether it's reports of bounties on the heads of Americans in Afghanistan,' he told reporters on Monday."
Russian reporting stating extension to be passed by Russian parliament on 5 Feb: https://twitter.com/pranayrvaddi/status/1354092436264542208

Both sides are eager to extend the treaty and have begun efforts to ensure it does not expire next week. The treaty benefits both the US and Russia, and checks a security dilemma and arms race (that Russia cannot afford). The Trump administration was willing to let the treaty lapse because it was a "bad deal" for the US, saying that it only covered long-range nuclear weapons. However, letting the treaty lapse with no other plan in place would likely be more dangerous for both the number and types of nuclear weapons currently allowed. Additionally, it was thought letting New START lapse would allow for a new treaty that would include China, but the PRC has signaled it's not interested in entering a treaty like New START any time soon. https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-01-26/kremlin-says-vigorous-efforts-needed-to-extend-russia-us-new-start-arms-treaty https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2021/01/new-start-nukes-russia.html

Given the amount of recent media reports on this I'm going all in with 100%. Over the last few days (week really) U.S. statements confirming their wish to extend have piled up and Russia has absolutely no reason not to want the same (on the contrary). How long to extend is the question, but I struggle to see any reason that they couldn't agree before the deadline.
Yep, will definitely do it. All in.

"[...]new Biden administration publicly announce its strong interest to immediately extend the strategic New START nuclear treaty with Russia that is set to expire next week, on Feb. 5. This came after Biden announced his commitment to philosophically and substantively reenter the multi-national world[...] Russian President Vladimir Putin has also stated several times Russia’s openness to extend the treaty." https://thehill.com/opinion/national-security/535570-urgent-extend-new-start-treaty-with-russia-now
The Biden administration announced that it will seek a full five year extension to New START. Putin announced last Wednesday that Russia remains committed to extending New START.
Both USA and Russia have signaled willingness. A complicating factor could arise and block, but that's unlikely since it would mean Putin or Biden taking a destructive attitude to the world system.
Adjusting to reflect the article from @Kogo
Biden wants to extend; apparently Putin does as well: https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Foreign-Policy/2021/0122/An-encouraging-step-Russia-and-US-to-extend-nuclear-treaty?icid=rss

I still see a lot of back and forth in nuclear social media commentary on how the new administration ought to approach this, and have not yet seen anything official from the new admin itself. I agree with other posters that it ought to happen, but don't believe the available data warrants the 90-100% certainty other folks are laying down.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-nuclear/biden-seeks-five-year-extension-of-new-start-arms-treaty-with-russia-idUSKBN29Q2I4 https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-international-news-vladimir-putin-dmitry-medvedev-russia-6730cb38e8253a02d83c562841e7ed00 About as close to a sure thing as you get in this area of endeavour. I'm a bit skittish about going to 100%, but wotthehell.

Biden plans to extend it for 5 years https://www.defensenews.com/smr/nuclear-arsenal/2021/01/21/biden-proposing-5-year-extension-of-nuke-treaty-with-russia-says-us-official/?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=EBB%2001.22.21&utm_term=Editorial%20-%20Early%20Bird%20Brief

President Biden has stated he is seeking an extension for New START. However, there can always be doubt in the process as a key negotiating function of nuclear treaties is presenting terms which the other side will be forced to decline, allowing one to cast blame for propaganda purposes (Truman's NSC 112). Additionally, the rhetoric in the cable that the U.S. remains "clear eyed about the challenges Russia poses,” and that the Biden administration “will work in close consultation with our Allies and partners to hold Russia to account for its reckless and aggressive actions” could lead Putin to press negotiations for an advantage. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/biden-administration-approach-russia-about-extension-new-start-nuclear-treaty-n1255187 https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1951v01/d131 [NSC 112]
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-nuclear-idUSKBN29Q2I4

Secretary of State-designate Antony Blinken said during his confirmation hearing Tuesday that President Joe Biden intended to seek an extension of the treaty, but suggested he had not made a decision on the length of that extension.

Update to original forecast: from 95% to 98%. Now that the Biden administration has taken over, they, as of today, have confirmed plans to seek a 5 year extension to the treaty before the 6 Feb expiration date.
President Biden will seek a five-year extension of the New START nuclear arms control pact with Russia before it expires on Feb. 5, senior officials told the Washington Post. (Axios)

"President Biden is seeking a five-year extension with Russia on the only remaining treaty limiting the world’s two largest nuclear arsenals just days before it expires, said two senior U.S. officials ... The decision to seek a five-year treaty extension, which Russia supports but the Biden administration hadn’t settled on until now, reflects the rapidly approaching deadline for Washington to renew the New START pact Feb. 5, the officials said." https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/biden-russia-nuclear-treaty-extension/2021/01/21/4667a11e-5b40-11eb-aaad-93988621dd28_story.html
The Biden administration's Secretary of State has stated that the US will look to extend New START and that it is a top priority for the State Department [1].
Joe Biden has said that if he is elected president, he will pursue the treaty’s extension without conditions.

President Biden and Secretary of State Blinken have confirmed the desire to extend the START treaty, per Reuters. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-state-arms/biden-will-seek-to-extend-new-start-treaty-must-decide-how-long-idUSKBN29O2QC?il=0
Antony Blinken has said that the Biden administration will seek to extend it. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-state-arms-idUSKBN29O2QC

This is not only a logical choice, but a poor time for the US to allow the treaty to expire for political, social, and economic reasons (even if they wanted to). I do not see any rational justification for not renewing a treaty that was in place by the incoming President when he was part of the administration that previously signed it. The duration of its extension may be changed, but not whether it will be renewed.

“Biden has spoken in favor of the preservation of the New START treaty, which was negotiated during his tenure as US vice president, and Russia has said it's open for its quick and unconditional extension.” Source: ISRAEL HAYOM
No change

US and Russia both in favor of an extension, with Russia proposing a 1 year extension while details for a longer agreement are negotiated with the Biden admin. https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2021/01/15/for-russia-nuclear-arms-curbs-with-biden-are-a-no-brainer-.html
Medvedev has suggested Biden is being "very optimistic" in the extension of START III, here's hoping that we prefer a feisty peace to anything else. The full quote is as follows;

This is complicated, but first week on the job, I don't think Biden (or Putin) wants to be the one responsible for this failing. Open Skies is one thing (don't look at my stuff,) START is another (I want to destroy all your stuff.) As the article notes, Putin may make demands, but really who has much room to debate here... https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/world/europe/russia-open-skies-treaty-biden.html

Considering this further and thinking about the incentives in a Biden administration to push this through, coupled with past signals from Russia that they desire continuation, I am revising my estimate upward.

Reevaluating my 99% forecast, I keep it the same. Recent articles confirm extending the Treaty is one of POTUS-elect Biden's near-term objectives. Bonus points: Senate confirmation (extra bureaucratic step) isn't required per the article below.

Biden will want a swift extension to new START (https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/29/politics/biden-nuclear-cuts-arms-control-russia/index.html, https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/1/11/gorbachev-expects-biden-to-extend-last-cold-war-arms-deal).
After determining that the old START treaty expires on 5 Feb--yes, this will get extended.

It appears both sides want to extend the START treaty based on the articles below: https://www.rferl.org/a/united-states-russia-new-start-treaty-negotiations/31007017.html https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-putin-weapons/putin-calls-on-u-s-to-extend-new-start-arms-control-treaty-for-one-year-idUSKBN28R1TO

So, Russia is reported to be minded to extend New START, why would this be? You cannot rely on or trust the Russian govt at all. If they're positive on extending New START it means they are getting a benefit and remember they have been regularly accused of cheating on these kind of treaties (surely not). As for Mr Biden, he expressed a view of being minded to extend; however, he's not been party to the detail of what Russia has actually been doing nor, until the government transition period started in December 2020, has he seen what the US has actually been doing, in any detail. Once Mr Biden understands the real situation he may be less keen on extending and more keen on re-negotiating, hence 50%

I find the rationals of @Ryan-Beck @vaguecommunicator @incognito @ajg convinced. And since the question is open, forecasters are rather convergent towards a probability higher than 90 or even 95%. However, there are only 3 weeks left, hence the absence of 100%.
To extend this is trivial, and both sides are open about wanting to do so. It is for all intents and purposes already done.

It seems that both sides (US/Russia) want to extend the treaty, and is in both parties interest to do so. As Biden takes hold of the new administration, I do not believe this is an area he is willing to or has interest in dissolving.

The new administration has expressed a desire to extend NEW START, it is also in both parties interest to do so. Forming a whole new agreement would also take time, it is far easier to extend the existing treaty. It is also sets a good tone for the new administration and Putin at the start of Biden’s first term.
I'm upping the likelihood of this happening.

Given this critical timeline and the priority it represents for the incoming National Security team, it is likely to be extended to maintain stability for further negotiation. The real question is probably how long of an extension will be agreed upon...
In both sides’ interest to avoid expensive proliferation.

Both sides seem eager to extend START. Despite only 2 weeks or so remaining in the treaty after Inauguration Day, the condensed time factor is not a hugely big deal given that an extension merely requires an exchange of diplomatic notes between the US and Russia and does not require Congressional involvement.

Both Putin and Biden have made overtures that they wish to extend the treaty because it serves both parties’ interests. Further, Biden has mentioned that he is willing to accept a deal without the strict verification measures that was one of the key sticking points between Trumps administration and the Kremlin. Lastly, Biden will have little trouble getting whatever agreement he views as adequate through congress. https://www.politico.eu/article/us-and-russia-poised-to-extend-new-start-treaty/ https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-putin-weapons/putin-calls-on-u-s-to-extend-new-start-arms-control-treaty-for-one-year-idUSKBN28R1TO https://www.nti.org/learn/treaties-and-regimes/treaty-between-the-united-states-of-america-and-the-russian-federation-on-measures-for-the-further-reduction-and-limitation-of-strategic-offensive-arms/ https://www.kitsapsun.com/story/news/2020/11/23/biden-signals-push-extend-new-start-nuclear-arms-treaty/6315771002/

It seems like both sides want this done, Biden seems like he intends to extend it. However, the short time frame makes things risky. I'd probably be a bit lower but I'm hedging toward the crowd a bit by going up to 90, though overall I do think it's likely.

Given the limited time between the inauguration and expiration of this deal, it seems unlikely that a superseding agreement can be reached in time. The only other way I can think that is becomes a "no" is if one or both parties are not willing to work with each other at all. Perhaps there is some risk of that outcome given the tensions and accusations by the incoming party. But, because the issue is so important to foreign policy and because the process can be swift, the most likely outcome seems to be an unchanged extension of the current agreement.

Putin (along with other Russian officials) has stated his wish to extend the treaty, and a temporary extension seems to be in the best interests of both. Despite tense relations on other areas (like, say, hacking attributed to Russia) Jake Sullivan, Biden's National Security Advisor to be, has stated that the incoming administration would move swiftly to achieve this, according to The New York Times. As noted below, according to the Arms Control Association, Biden has expressed a will to extend without conditions. Since a congressional go-ahead is not required (according to NYT, NPR, etc.) it seems like like a temporary extension is both possible and likely, ahead of some sort of broader discussion at a later time. On the "no" side of the argument is mainly whether there will be enough time.

Both President-Elect Biden and President Putin have publicly announced a commitment to extend the New START treaty. President-Elect Biden promised to pursue an extension to New Start during the first days of his presidency. President Putin declared that he is ready to extend New START without any preconditions. By signing a five year extension, both countries would have time to contemplate the additional steps to be taken. The deadline is approaching quickly and this seems the likely course of action.
Incoming admin is in favor, can extend via executive only. The first few weeks of the admin may be hectic, but this could be an "easy win." It could signal a dedication to foreign policy.

CAO 11 Jan. Assumptions: No more movement from Trump administration. Earliest to start working on the extension again is 20 Jan with a Biden inauguration. This gives 16 days to work out the extension. Unfortunately my forecast is more reliant on an ‘inside view’ than I would prefer. Positive factors: original New Start was negotiated by the Obama administration, and Biden sounds likely to want to continue that legacy. An extension without additional conditions is simpler than a negotiated agreement, and would set the Biden administration on a productive start with the Putin administration. Trump seems like he was happy to let it expire, while extending it would be a repudiation of sorts of Trump foreign policy, and perhaps increases the likelihood of the Biden administration trying to extend the treaty. Sullivan, incoming NSA has commented on plan to work to quickly renew the deal. Complicating factors: Democrats interested in holding Russia accountable for election interference. Biden statement that the US will 'respond in kind' for the extensive cyber attacks that were made know 1-2 weeks ago. Putin could use this as a first test of the administration.
Just seems unlikely that the US would rush into an agreement.

Although the Biden administration would only have two weeks to extend the New START before February 6, 2021, there have been indications that they plan to address this issue quickly after the inauguration and Russia previously proposed to extend New START without any conditions. Prior to the recent Russian hack, I would have given this question an almost certain outcome more consistent with the current crowd forecast of 99%. It is unclear how the US response to the Russian hack could affect the Biden administration's relationship with Russia, or whether it would impact New START extension.

Both Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Elect Joseph Biden have publicly expressed support for renewing the New START (Biden in October 2020 and Putin in December 2020). Additionally, President Elect Biden is very familiar with the treaty, having worked on New START as Vice President during the Obama Administration. Under these circumstances, I would ordinarily put the probability of renewal very high, at 90+%. However, the extraordinary events of the last week warrant a lower level of certainty.

Biden administration values the treaty and is bringing in the experience to make it happen. Putin has signaled 1-5 year extension options, but to-be-discussed with new administration. The START treaty gives Putin a presence on the world stage, too, even though he'd arguably get a bigger presence if he did NOT come to agreement.
After reviewing other forecasts and seeing some of the options for flawed/rushed extensions, I am revising my estimate upward.

The US has historically been in favor of nuclear arms control treaties with Russia. Additionally, Russia has made a variety of statements in recent months indicating a general willingness to renew the treaty. Overall, it's likely that the Biden administration will return to New START or something similar. However, given domestic challenges in the US and the general friction of a new administration, it seems unlikely that this will be taken up quickly enough for this forecast. Even if it were to be taken up immediately, 20 January to 6 February is a pretty tight turn. I rate this not-very-likely due to the timetable.

Bottom line-up front: There just does not seem to be enough information to make a solid assessment of the likelihood of this specific agreement being extended. Both sides want to sign the treaty, but there is not much time to get it done following Biden's inaugeration.
99% yes it will be extended. Both sides (Putin, Biden) desire the extension, and it maintains the status quo while giving time for additional/different/new negotiations.

Jake Sullivan, the incoming National Security Advisor, said on January 3 that the new administration would move quickly to renew the last remaining major nuclear arms treaty with Russia. His announcement came after the revelation that Russia is likely the culprit in the Solar Winds cyber attack. If such an attack does not deter the new administration from supporting extension of the treaty, it is hard to imagine other actions Russia might take that would change the U.S. administration's calculus on this question. The Biden administration sees the extension as a much-needed framework for stability.
Flawed extension better than nothing.
Going with the crowd but more so..
Reflecting that a temp extension to enable renegotiation is more likely

While i expect a renegotiated, de facto extension of New START due to the incoming Biden administration's declared desire to enhance arms control, i don't think there is enough time to achieve this within the time available. Unless they are working this issue already, i think a new agreement is more likely than an extended one

The administration had been holding up a renewal of START as it wanted to broaden the scope to include China concerning nuclear weapons proliferation and extend the Treaty for just 12 months. Putin has expressed his ambition on December 5th, 2020, to renew for five years but without any conditions. It is relevant to note that Russia has previously requested the inclusion of UK and France with their nuclear capability. However, the Trump administration did not withdraw from the START treaty (rather than withdraw completely) but failed to extend. It would appear that the Biden administration intends to extend the New START and could quickly communicate an extension offer without conditions.
Up 5% to be ahead of the consensus. Expect "normal" to be the new norm. —or at least hope so.

The Russians seem to be holding out to negotiate with the Biden administration, and 16 days just isn't enough time to negotiate a treaty. In addition, there are roadblocks because the Russians oppose strict verification measures, which the US is likely to want due to Russian violations of the previous START treaty.

The signs are pretty clear that extension is intended leaving the primary question of whether there is adequate time. Down to 80% on the chance that merely a joint statement gets issued until an official treaty defined extension is completed.
Biden supports this, it's easy to extend, will illustrate early how Biden can solve problems. As I understand it, Putin already supported this previously.
Initial forecast. In spite of various claims, in the interest of both parties. More likely for 1 or 2 years to allow some constructive dialog.
